OVERVIEW: The Dinevo series consists of deep, well drained soils that formed in alluvium from igneous and sedimentary rocks.  Dinevo soils are on old alluvial fans and have slopes of 0 to 5 percent.  The mean annual precipitation is about 10 inches, and the mean annual air temperature is about 50 degrees F.

TAXONOMIC CLASS.content: TAXONOMIC CLASS: Fine-loamy, mixed, superactive, mesic Haploxerollic Natrargids

TYPICAL PEDON.content:
TYPICAL PEDON:  Dinevo sandy loam, rangeland.  (Colors are for dry soil unless otherwise noted.)
A11--0 to 2 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) sandy loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; weak medium platy structure that parts to weak thin platy; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few very fine roots; few very fine tubular pores; 5 percent gravel; moderately alkaline (pH 8.0); abrupt wavy boundary.  (2 to 5 inches thick)
A12--2 to 4 inches; pale brown (10YR 6/3) sandy loam, dark yellowish brown (10YR 4/4) moist; weak thick platy structure that parts to weak very fine granular; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few very fine roots; few very fine tubular pores; 5 percent gravel; moderately alkaline (pH 8.0); abrupt wavy boundary.  (0 to 4 inches thick)
B2t--4 to 12 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) clay loam, dark brown (7.5YR 4/4) moist; moderate medium prismatic structure that parts to moderate fine subangular blocky; hard, firm, sticky and plastic; few fine and medium and common very fine roots; common fine and very fine tubular pores; many moderately thick clay films on faces of ped; 5 percent gravel; strongly alkaline (pH 8.6); gradual smooth boundary.  (5 to 8 inches thick)
B3tca--12 to 16 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/4) clay loam, strong brown (7.5YR 4/6) moist; moderate medium subangular blocky structure that parts to moderate fine and very fine subangular blocky; hard, friable, sticky and plastic; few fine and very fine roots; few fine and common very fine tubular pores; 10 percent gravel; moderately calcareous, lime disseminated and in common fine accretions; strongly alkaline (pH 9.0); abrupt smooth boundary.  (4 to 7 inches thick)
C1ca--16 to 31 inches; white (10YR 8/2) fine sandy loam, light yellowish brown (10YR 6/4) moist; weak coarse subangular blocky structure that parts to weak fine subangular blocky; hard, friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few fine and common very fine tubular pores; 10 percent gravel; strongly calcareous, lime disseminated and weakly cemented; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); clear smooth boundary.  (8 to 17 inches thick)
C2ca--31 to 41 inches; pink (7.5YR 7/3) sandy loam, brown (7.5YR 5/4) moist; moderate medium subangular structure that parts to weak very fine subangular blocky; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few fine roots; few fine and very fine tubular pores; 15 percent gravel; strongly calcareous, lime disseminated; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); clear wavy boundary.  (6 to 15 inches thick)
IIC3ca--41 to 59 inches; pink (7.5YR 7/3) gravelly sandy loam, brown (7.5YR 5/4) moist; massive; slightly hard, very friable, nonsticky and nonplastic; few fine roots; common fine and very fine interstitial pores; 35 percent gravel; moderately calcareous, lime disseminated; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4); gradual wavy boundary.  (5 to 25 inches thick)
IIIC4--59 to 65 inches; brown (7.5YR 5/3) gravelly sand, dark brown (7.5YR 4/3) moist; single grained; loose; many fine and very fine interstitial pores; 40 percent gravel; slightly calcareous, lime disseminated; moderately alkaline (pH 8.4).

TYPE LOCATION.content: TYPE LOCATION:  Iron County, Utah; about 6 miles west of Iron Springs along the Antelope Road; 2,600 feet east of the southwest corner of section 5, T.35S., R.13W.

RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS.content:
RANGE IN CHARACTERISTICS:  The combined thickness of the A and B horizons is 16 to 19 inches.  There is 1 to 2 percent organic matter in the upper 16 inches of the soil.  There is less than 15 percent sodium in the upper part of the natric horizon.  Depth to secondary carbonates is 10 to 16 inches and carbonate equivalent ranges from 10 to 40 percent.  The argillic horizon has 27 to 35 percent clay and more than 15 percent fine sand or coarser.  The mean annual soil temperature at depth of 20 inches ranges from 50 degrees to 53 degrees F. and the mean summer soil temperature ranges from 67 degrees to 71 degrees F.  These soils are dry more than one/half the time the soil temperature is above 41 degrees F., but are continually moist 25 to 30 percent of the time.  The A horizon has hue of 10YR or 7.5YR, value of 5 or 6 dry, 3 or 4 moist and chroma of 2 through 4.  The value of 5 dry and 3 moist occur only in the upper 2 or 3 inches.  This horizon ranges from sandy loam to sandy clay, loam and contains 0 to 15 percent rock fragments.  It is 3 to 6 inches thick.
The B2t horizon has prismatic structure that parts to moderate very fine through coarse subangular blocky.  It ranges from clay loam to sandy clay loam and has 0 to 10 percent rock fragments.  This horizon is moderately or strongly alkaline.
The B3tca horizon has value of 5 or 6 dry, 3 or 4 moist and chroma of 3 through 6.  It ranges from clay loam to sandy clay loam and has 0 to 15 percent rock fragments.  This horizon is moderately or strongly calcareous and strongly or very strongly alkaline.
The Cca horizon has value of 6 through 8 dry.  It is fine sandy loam, sandy loam, gravelly sandy loam, clay loam, or loam and has 0 to 40 percent rock fragments.  This horizon is moderately or strongly calcareous, moderately through very strongly alkaline and is 19 to 43 inches thick.)

COMPETING SERIES.content: COMPETING SERIES:  Presently no other soils are classified in the same family.  Some similar soils are the Antelope Springs, Bullion, Mellor and Rumbo series.  Antelope Springs, Bullion and Mellor soil have 15 percent or more saturation with sodium through the major part of the natric horizon.  Bullion soils have 5YR hue in the B2t horizon and are fine.  Mellow soils are fine-silty.  Rumbo soils are fine, montmorillonitic.

GEOGRAPHIC SETTING.content: GEOGRAPHIC SETTING:  Dinevo soils are at elevations of 5,100 to 5,900 feet.  They occur on all aspects of old dissected alluvial fans and formed in mixed alluvium from igneous and sedimentary rocks.  Slopes range from 0 to 5 percent.  The climate is semiarid and average annual precipitation ranges from 9 to 12 inches.  Mean annual temperature is 48 degrees to 51 degrees F. and mean summer temperature is 68 to 72 degrees F.  The frost-free period is 110 to 130 days.

GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS.content: GEOGRAPHICALLY ASSOCIATED SOILS:  These are the Ashdown (t), Checkett, Dixie, Hiko Peak and Wales soils and the competing Antelope Springs soils.  Ashdown, Hiko Peak and Wales soils lack natric horizons.  Checkett and Dixie soils have argillic horizons but lack natric horizons.

DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY.content: DRAINAGE AND PERMEABILITY:  Well drained; slow runoff; moderately slow permeability in the B2t horizon and rapid permeability in the IIIC horizon.

USE AND VEGETATION.content: USE AND VEGETATION:  These soils are used for rangeland and wildlife habitat.  Present native vegetation is big sagebrush, snakweed, globemallow, Russian thistle, loco weed, sand dropseed, galleta, threeawn and squirreltail.

DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT.content: DISTRIBUTION AND EXTENT:  Southwestern Utah.  This series is moderately extensive.

REGIONAL OFFICE.section: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE
REGIONAL OFFICE.content: MLRA SOIL SURVEY REGIONAL OFFICE (MO) RESPONSIBLE: Davis, California

ORIGIN.content:
SERIES PROPOSED:  Buckhorn-Cedar Area, Iron County, Utah 1975.
OSED scanned by SSQA.  Last reviewed by state 4/76.
